OVERVIEW: The Kizhuyak series consists of deep, poorly drained soils formed in alluvium consisting of volcanic ash.  Kizhuyak soils are on floodplains.  Slopes range from 0 to 3 percent.  Mean annual temperature is about 40 degrees F., and the average annual precipitation is about 60 inches.

TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Ashy, glassy, acid Aquandic Cryaquents

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Kizhuyak loamy fine sand -- under native grasses and sedges  (All colors are for moist soil)
Oi--1 inch to 0; dark brown (7.5YR 3/2) mat of roots and straw; few mycelia; very strongly acid; abrupt smooth boundary.  (1 to 4 inches thick)
C1--0 to 4 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) loamy fine sand; mottled with yellowish red; single grain; loose; few roots; strongly acid; abrupt wavy boundary.  (3 to 12 inches thick)
C2--4 to 27 inches; stratified grayish brown (10YR 5/2) silt loam and light gray (10YR 7/2) loamy fine sand; silt strata are massive and firm; loamy fine sand strata are single grained and loose; individual strata usually less than 1 inch thick; thin streaks of yellowish red along root channels; few roots; strongly acid; abrupt wavy boundary.
C3--27 to 40 inches; light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) silt loam; massive; firm; occasional streaks of light gray; strongly acid.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Northeastern Kodiak Island Area, Alaska.  Saltery Cove Road, 0.1 mile south of junction with Chiniak Cape Road at Middle Bay.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content: RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The volcanic ash accumulation is more than 40 inches thick.  The ash may be mottled, especially in the upper 20 inches.  Texture in the uppermost layer and throughout the profile ranges from silt loam to fine sand.  The underlying material is usually silty alluvium, but may be coarse sand, gravel, or peat.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  This is the Chock series in the same subgroup.  Chock soils are medial in the control section and have pH greater than 5.5 (H20,1:1)

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Kizhuyak soils are on floodplains near the mouths of streams.  The parent material is volcanic ash washed from hills bordering the floodplains.  The climate is cool maritime.  Averageannual preci itation ranges from 50 to 70 inches, and the average annual temperature is about 40 degrees F.  Temperatures below freezing are recorded on fewer than 40 days annually, and temperatures above 70 degrees F. are rare.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These include the Chiniak, Kalsin, and Salonie series.  Chiniak soils are underlain by gravelly beach dune material.  Kalsin soils are formed in moderately deep to deep, dark silty alluvial material.  Salonie soils are formed in shallow silty alluvial material overlying gravel.:

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Poorly drained.  Some pedons have altered drainage due to stream incisement.  Permeability is moderate.  Runoff is slow.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  Used mostly for grazing.  The natural vegetation consists principally of water tolerant grasses and sedges.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Northern Kodiak Island, Alaska, and adjacent islands.  The series is of minor extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.content: SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (SSRO) RESPONSIBLE: WASILLA, ALASKA

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Northeastern Kodiak Island Area, Alaska, 1959.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  The concept of the Kalsin series is poorly defined.  More data is needed to define the central concept or the series should be inactivated (jpm, 4/87).
Source of the volcanic ash is the 1912 eruption of Mt. Novarupta and Mt.  Katmai on the Alaska Peninsula.

HORIZONS.name: C1
HORIZONS.narrative: C1--0 to 4 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) loamy fine sand; mottled with yellowish red; single grain; loose; few roots; strongly acid; abrupt wavy boundary.  (3 to 12 inches thick)

HORIZONS.narrative: C2--4 to 27 inches; stratified grayish brown (10YR 5/2) silt loam and light gray (10YR 7/2) loamy fine sand; silt strata are massive and firm; loamy fine sand strata are single grained and loose; individual strata usually less than 1 inch thick; thin streaks of yellowish red along root channels; few roots; strongly acid; abrupt wavy boundary.

HORIZONS.name: C3
HORIZONS.narrative: C3--27 to 40 inches; light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) silt loam; massive; firm; occasional streaks of light gray; strongly acid.

HORIZONS.name: Oi
HORIZONS.narrative: Oi--1 inch to 0; dark brown (7.5YR 3/2) mat of roots and straw; few mycelia; very strongly acid; abrupt smooth boundary.  (1 to 4 inches thick)
